comment_text.mn52:1.2: The Buddha spent his last rains retreat here (SN 47.9:1.5, DN 16:2.22.3). The fact that the Buddha is not mentioned and the setting at Pāṭaliputta suggest that he had already passed away.
comment_text.mn52:1.3: Dasama means “tenth”, explained by the commentary as meaning he was tenth in line in his family. | Aṭṭhakanāgara is usually taken to be the name of a city, but neither the city nor the possessive form nāgara appear elsewhere. Since all we know of him is that he was very rich; since the Pali is in the habit of naming people after their prominent quality; and since we find elsewhere a man named after his wealth (Dhaniya at Snp 1.2), perhaps we should take aṭṭhaka from artha in the sense of “wealthy”, which agrees with the later Sanskrit sense of nāgara as “prominent citizen”.
comment_text.mn52:2.1: With the rise of Pāṭaliputta, this became an important monastery after the Buddha’s passing. Malalasekera (Dictionary of Pali Proper Names) suggests it was the same monastery later renowned as Aśokārāma. Ānanda stayed there often (SN 45.18–20, SN 47.21–3), which explains why Dasama expected to find him there.
comment_text.mn52:3.1: Beluva was immediately north of Vesālī, so about a day’s walk from Pāṭaliputta. But Dasama could doubtless afford a carriage.
comment_text.mn52:3.2: A number of “one things” are taught throughout the suttas. It seems Dasama wanted a simple summary, but Ānanda wished to challenge him.
comment_text.mn52:4.3: This illustrates the development of insight based on absorption. After emerging from the attainment, the meditator reflects on the nature of that experience, realizing that even the most blissful and peaceful of states is still “chosen and intended” (abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ), i.e. constructed by volition.
comment_text.mn52:4.5: Insight must persist to bear fruit.
comment_text.mn52:4.6: “Passion and love for that meditation” (teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā); here dhamma means the state of meditation, i.e. the jhāna. This is the “higher fetter” of rūparāga, the desire for birth in the Brahmā realms of luminous form.
comment_text.mn52:14.7: Ānanda omits the final formless attainment, neither perception nor non-perception, which is not regarded as a basis for insight due to its extreme subtlety. See too MN 64:15.5.
comment_text.mn52:15.3: “For cultivation”: variants include bhāvanāya, savanāya, and sevanāya. The center point of these is sevanāya, which is a synonym of bhāvanāya and near-homonym of savanāya. Also, the sense of savanāya should be “for hearing”, but he has already heard them, so they are now “for cultivation”.
comment_text.mn52:15.5: Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.2.1 speaks of “a city with eleven doors of the unborn”. Śaṅkara identifies these as the apertures of the body: eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, navel, genitals, anus, and the spiritual opening at the crown of the head.
comment_text.mn52:15.6: “Fee for the teacher”: ācariyadhana. | “Other religions” is in reference to the Brahmanical dakṣiṇā.
comment_text.mn52:16.2: This lavish demonstration of Dasama’s wealth is an early indication of the largess enjoyed by the Sangha in Pāṭaliputta. Over a century later, under Ashoka, so many corrupt individuals entered the Sangha seeking profits that a Council had to be held to expel them.

root_text.mn52:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṁ viharati beluvagāmake.
root_text.mn52:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputtaṁ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
root_text.mn52:2.1: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro yena kukkuṭārāmo yena aññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn52:2.2: “kahaṁ nu kho, bhante, āyasmā ānando etarahi viharati?
root_text.mn52:2.3: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṁ taṁ āyasmantaṁ ānandan”ti.
root_text.mn52:2.4: “Eso, gahapati, āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṁ viharati beluvagāmake”ti.
root_text.mn52:3.1: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputte taṁ karaṇīyaṁ tīretvā yena vesālī yena beluvagāmako yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn52:3.2: “atthi nu kho, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo akkhāto yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttañceva cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti?
root_text.mn52:3.3: “Atthi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo akkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttañceva cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
root_text.mn52:3.4: “Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo akkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttañceva cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti?
root_text.mn52:4.1: “Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:4.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:4.5: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti.
root_text.mn52:4.6: No ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
root_text.mn52:4.7: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo akkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttañceva cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
root_text.mn52:5.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:6.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:7.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:8.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.mn52:8.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:9.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
root_text.mn52:11.1: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.mn52:11.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:12.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:12.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:13.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:13.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:14.1: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn52:14.4: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn52:14.5: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti.
root_text.mn52:14.6: No ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
root_text.mn52:14.7: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo akkhāto yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttañceva cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā ca āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattañca anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
root_text.mn52:15.1: Evaṁ vutte, dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn52:15.2: “seyyathāpi, bhante ānanda, puriso ekaṁva nidhimukhaṁ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa nidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya;
root_text.mn52:15.3: evameva kho ahaṁ, bhante, ekaṁ amatadvāraṁ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa amatadvārāni alatthaṁ bhāvanāya.
root_text.mn52:15.4: Seyyathāpi, bhante, purisassa agāraṁ ekādasadvāraṁ, so tasmiṁ agāre āditte ekamekenapi dvārena sakkuṇeyya attānaṁ sotthiṁ kātuṁ;
root_text.mn52:15.5: evameva kho ahaṁ, bhante, imesaṁ ekādasannaṁ amatadvārānaṁ ekamekenapi amatadvārena sakkuṇissāmi attānaṁ sotthiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn52:15.6: Imehi nāma, bhante, aññatitthiyā ācariyassa ācariyadhanaṁ pariyesissanti, kimaṅgaṁ panāhaṁ āyasmato ānandassa pūjaṁ na karissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn52:16.1: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputtakañca vesālikañca bhikkhusaṅghaṁ sannipātetvā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi,
root_text.mn52:16.2: ekamekañca bhikkhuṁ paccekaṁ dussayugena acchādesi, āyasmantañca ānandaṁ ticīvarena acchādesi, āyasmato ca ānandassa pañcasatavihāraṁ kārāpesīti.

translation_text.mn52:1.2: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.
translation_text.mn52:1.3: Now at that time the householder Dasama, a wealthy citizen, had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business.
translation_text.mn52:2.1: He went to the Chicken Monastery, approached a certain mendicant, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn52:2.2: “Sir, where is Venerable Ānanda now staying?
translation_text.mn52:2.3: For I want to see him.”
translation_text.mn52:2.4: “Householder, Venerable Ānanda is staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.”
translation_text.mn52:3.1: Then the householder Dasama, having concluded his business there, went to the little village of Beluva in Vesālī to see Ānanda. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
translation_text.mn52:3.2: “Honorable Ānanda, is there one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke?”
translation_text.mn52:4.1: “Householder, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn52:4.3: ‘Even this first absorption is produced by choices and intentions.’
translation_text.mn52:4.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’
translation_text.mn52:4.5: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn52:4.6: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn52:4.7: This is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn52:5.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn52:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn52:8.3: ‘Even this heart’s release by love is produced by choices and intentions.’
translation_text.mn52:8.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …
translation_text.mn52:9.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.mn52:12.1: Furthermore, householder, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.mn52:12.3: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of infinite space is produced by choices and intentions.’
translation_text.mn52:12.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …
translation_text.mn52:13.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …
translation_text.mn52:14.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn52:14.3: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of nothingness is produced by choices and intentions.’
translation_text.mn52:14.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’
translation_text.mn52:14.5: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn52:14.6: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn52:14.7: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”
translation_text.mn52:15.1: When he said this, the householder Dasama said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.mn52:15.2: “Honorable Ānanda, suppose a person was looking for the entrance to a treasure trove. And all at once they’d come across eleven entrances!
translation_text.mn52:15.3: In the same way, I was searching for the door to freedom from death. And all at once I found eleven doors to freedom from death for cultivation.
translation_text.mn52:15.4: Suppose a person had a house with eleven doors. If the house caught fire they’d be able to flee to safety through any one of those doors.
translation_text.mn52:15.5: In the same way, I’m able to flee to safety through any one of these eleven doors to freedom from death.
translation_text.mn52:15.6: Sir, those of other religions seek a fee for the tutor. Why shouldn’t I make an offering to Venerable Ānanda?”
translation_text.mn52:16.1: Then the householder Dasama, having assembled the Saṅgha from Vesālī and Pāṭaliputta, served and satisfied them with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.mn52:16.2: He clothed each and every mendicant in a pair of garments, with a set of three robes for Ānanda. And he had a dwelling worth five hundred built for Ānanda.
